summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting a proffer interview with a former Bureau of Prisons Corrections Officer (CO) from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The interviewee provides detailed information about his work history, duties, and observations regarding contraband, security procedures, and a specific incident involving a gun lockdown and subsequent searches. He also discusses allegations against himself and other officers, including rumors of passing contraband.

events.title: Proffer Interview of Michael Thomas
events.description: Former MCC Corrections Officer Michael Thomas is interviewed under a proffer agreement by SDNY AUSAs and FBI agents. He provides information about MCC operations, contraband, and a specific gun lockdown incident.

events.title: Gun Lockdown at MCC
events.description: A gun was reportedly discovered inside the MCC, leading to a lockdown. Officers from other prisons (FCI Fort Dix and Danbury) were called in. The DCT was activated to search inmate units and cells for contraband.

events.title: Michael Thomas Placed on Administrative Leave
events.description: Following the SHU incident during the gun lockdown searches, Thomas received a phone call informing him he was placed on administrative leave. Posters were made stating he was not allowed in the building.

events.title: Thomas's Employment at MCC
events.description: Michael Thomas worked at the Metropolitan Correctional Center from July 2011 until 2020, serving as a Corrections Officer, Senior Officer Specialist, and member/instructor of the Disturbance Control Team.

locations: United States Attorney's Office, 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The interviewee, Michael Thomas, a former MCC Corrections Officer, describes systemic contraband issues at the facility, including cell phones, drugs, and weapons being smuggled in via various methods, such as through trash cans and a rope/basket system from a window.

Thomas details a significant gun lockdown incident at the MCC, which required activation of the Disturbance Control Team and assistance from officers at other federal prisons to conduct extensive cell searches.
Thomas alleges that a fellow officer, Tamerlin Zeine, was recently involved in a shooting near his house in Brooklyn, but claims it had nothing to do with Zeine.
Thomas and other officers (Zeine, Rios) were subsequently placed on administrative leave following the gun lockdown incident, with rumors spreading that they had passed a phone to an inmate.
Thomas admits to occasionally passing minor items like stamps to inmates, even in heightened security situations, claiming it could prevent worse problems, but denies passing serious contraband.
